newsitem.title: USA: Dow ends slightly higher in small rebound.
newsitem.headline: Dow ends slightly higher in small rebound.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks closed moderately higher on Tuesday in a small rebound after a sharp two-session sell-off sparked by fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again soon.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.57 points to 6,611.05. Analysts were quick to caution, however, that the gains wiped out only a small fraction of the nearly 300-point loss the Dow index has suffered since last Thursday.
Several said that despite the welcome respite, the outlook will remain extremely uncertain, at least as long as the questions that triggered the decline go unanswered.

"My sense is we're still in the midst of a painful period that still has a way to go," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co. "But there's still a lot of uncertainty ahead and will be until we have a better handle on what the Federal Reserve will do next."
Analysts noted that pharmaceutical and finance stocks posted a solid day, notable because the groups have led the market's roller-coaster ride this year.
"The two leadership groups, banks and drugs, were trying to reassert their leadership today," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
Chase Manhattan Corp. gained 1-5/8 to 95-1/2, Citicorp rose 4-1/4 to 112-1/2 and Dow component J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc. added 1-5/8 to 99-7/8.
Among drug companies, Dow stock Merck & Co. Inc. rose 2-3/8 to 86-5/8 and Pfizer Inc. rose 7/8 to 85.
Another key sector, technology, failed to shake off the effects of its malaise. Analysts said any real reversal in the downturn would likely first take root among tech stocks.

"I think anyone watching for a bottom should watch the techs," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker. "Last July, the techs were the first group to go lower, first to bottom and first to turn higher again," he said.

While the group as a whole failed to match the modest rally in blue chips, some of the sector's bellwether stocks did show signs of life. Microsoft Corp. rose 1-9/16 to 93-1/4 and Intel Corp. rose 3/16 to 139-5/16.
Bonds rose despite a stronger-than-expected National Association of Purchasing Management report.
The key 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32, or $2.50 on a $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, edged down to 7.08 percent from 7.10 percent at Monday's close.
But with critical monthly payrolls, wage and unemployment data due Friday, the interest rate outlook remains far from clear, leaving market matters looking anything but certain.
"We're probably going to have more days like today for a while, up 20 points and then down 20," Bleier said. "But if rates go through 7.20 percent, all bets are off."

Among individual issues, database software firm Informix Corp. sank 5-7/32 to 9-29/32 and electronic systems design software maker Quickturn Design Systems Inc. lost 7-3/4 to 8-1/4, both after profit warnings.
Catalina Marketing Corp., a provider of in-store electronic marketing programmes for consumer-goods companies, sank 10-3/4 to 29-7/8, also after warning of disappointing quarterly results.

Embattled Canadian mining company Bre-X Minerals Ltd. rebounded a bit, rising 3/4 to 2-1/2 on Nasdaq after being halted all day Monday. Frantic trading in the stock caused computers at the Toronto Stock Exchange to crash.
The Nasdaq Composite index fell 4.77 points to 1,216.93.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks edged up 2.52 points to 759.64. The American Stock Exchange index lost 2.44 to 566.27.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.25 to 399.80. The average share was up 12 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,222.417, up 8.886, or 0.12 percent.
